key_points: Kyle Rittenhouse, charged with fatally shooting two during a Wisconsin protest, cannot associate with known white supremacists per judge's order.
Rittenhouse was 17 at the time of the shootings during a protest over the police shooting of Jacob Blake, a Black man.
He faces charges including reckless and intentional homicide, endangerment, and being a minor in possession of a firearm.
Prosecutors claim Rittenhouse traveled from Illinois to Wisconsin, joining militia groups to protect businesses during protests.
Rittenhouse has pleaded not guilty, asserting he acted in self-defense.
His bail conditions were modified after he was seen drinking in a bar and posing for a photo making a symbol used by white supremacists.
The modifications explicitly prohibit Rittenhouse from associating with groups known to harass others based on race, religion, color, national origin, or gender.
He is also barred from possessing firearms and consuming alcohol.
The bail condition modifications were requested following Rittenhouse's bar visit where he interacted with individuals linked to white supremacist groups.
Rittenhouse's case has drawn significant attention, with conservatives rallying to support him.
